title: Clinton Era Financial Deregulation and Wall Street Capture (1993-2001)
description: Research systematic financial industry capture during Clinton administration, focusing on Glass-Steagall repeal, derivatives deregulation, and revolving door between Treasury and Wall Street. Document how Clinton-era deregulation created infrastructure for 2008 financial crisis and established template for systematic regulatory capture that enabled later kleptocratic patterns.

key_sources.title: Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act legislative history and lobbying records
key_sources.why: Documents systematic Wall Street lobbying for deregulation

key_sources.title: Treasury Department personnel records and post-government employment
key_sources.why: Reveals revolving door between Treasury and Wall Street

key_sources.title: Clinton administration meeting logs with financial industry executives
key_sources.why: Documents direct industry influence on policy formation

key_sources.title: Commodity Futures Modernization Act drafting and passage records
key_sources.why: Shows derivatives industry capture of regulatory framework

expected_outcomes: Documents systematic Wall Street capture of Treasury Department
Reveals template for regulatory capture used in subsequent administrations
Shows connection between Clinton deregulation and 2008 financial crisis
Establishes foundation for understanding modern financial kleptocracy

connections.description: Clinton deregulation builds on Reagan-era anti-regulatory framework

research_notes: Focus on documenting systematic patterns rather than individual scandals. Clinton era established many institutional capture mechanisms that became templates for Bush/Trump administrations.
reprioritization_reason: Timeline coverage gap analysis - high value for unique content
